South Korea exports set to rise for ninth month on chip surge: Reuters Poll
data.description:
SEOUL, Feb 27 (Reuters) - South Korea's exports likely rose for a ninth straight month in February as a global boom in artificial intelligence investment drove a surge in chip sales, a Reuters poll showed on Friday.

Exports from Asia's fourth-largest economy, a bellwether for global trade, were projected to have risen 24.0% from a year earlier, according to a median forecast of nine economists.

That would be weaker than the 33.8% rise in January, when exports posted their strongest increase since August 2021, but still the second fastest year-on-year growth in the current streak that started in June 2025.

Data in January and February are often distorted due to timing differences in the Lunar New Year holidays, which were in February this year and January last year. There were 19 working days in February, compared with 22 in the same month a year before.

Chip prices are rising more sharply than expected, while stock inventories still remain low in South Korea and Taiwan, economists noted, as they expected strong momentum in semiconductor exports.

"There is a high possibility of semiconductor export growth exceeding 100% throughout the first half," said Stephen Lee, an analyst at Meritz Securities in Seoul.

"Still, there is little momentum in autos and machinery, weighed by tariff effects," Lee added.

In the first 20 days of this month, exports rose 23.5%, led by a 134.1% surge in semiconductors. Shipments to China rose 30.8%, while those to the U.S. and the European Union grew 21.9% and 11.4%, respectively.

South Korean policymakers said last week they would still follow through on a trade deal reached with Washington in November, amid renewed uncertainty in the wake of the U.S. Supreme Court's ruling that President Donald Trump's emergency tariffs are illegal.

The Bank of Korea on Thursday raised its economic growth forecast for this year to 2.0% from 1.8%, citing a chip boom in exports, as the central bank held interest rates steady and signalled policy would stay unchanged for the next six months.

In February, imports likely rose 13.0% from a year earlier, after increasing 11.6% in January, the survey also showed. That would mark the strongest rise since September 2022.

The median estimate for the monthly trade balance stood at a surplus of $10.0 billion, wider than $8.71 billion in the previous month.

South Korea is scheduled to report trade figures for February on Sunday, March 1, at 9 a.m. (0000 GMT).

(Reporting by Jihoon LeeEditing by Shri Navaratnam)

By Jihoon Lee

Sony Group Shares Surge After Expanding Share Buyback Plan
data.description:
By Jason Chau


Japanese conglomerate Sony Group's shares surged after the company again expanded its ongoing share buyback program.

Its stock was recently 6.5% higher around midday in Tokyo on Friday, on track for its largest single-day gain in almost five months.

The gains followed Sony's announcement on Thursday that it would expand its share repurchase program amount to as much as 250 billion yen, or $1.6 billion, from 150 billion yen. This was the second time it has expanded its buyback program after initially approving 100 billion yen in November last year.

The company now plans to repurchase up to 90 million shares by May, representing more than 1.5% of its outstanding shares. This is a substantial increase from the 55 million shares originally announced.

Sony said it had launched the share buyback in a bid to improve capital efficiency. It added that the plan was expanded to allow more flexibility in repurchases, after considering the current pace of buybacks and stock market trends.

The share price move may also reflect a shift in investor flows, as stocks of other gaming companies have also risen.

"Sony's stock increase is likely part of a broader movement to take profits on semiconductor-related stocks following Nvidia's earnings and to repurchase gaming-related stocks that had been recently sold off heavily," said Morningstar equity research director Kazunori Ito.

Sony's shares, which outperformed other gaming stocks, gained even further in reaction to the share buyback expansion, he added.

"We are seeing rotation into laggards like...Sony that [had] been trading woefully with AI and semiconductor related names sucking in all the flows," with the shift expected to continue into March, said Andrew Jackson, head of Japan equity strategy at Ortus Advisors.


Write to Jason Chau at jason.chau@wsj.com


(END) Dow Jones Newswires

02-26-26 2329ET

data.title: TBK & Sons Turns to Profit in Fiscal H1
Japan Government to Become Top Shareholder in Chipmaker Rapidus
data.description:
By Yang Jie


Japan's government is tightening its grip on the nation's fledgling semiconductor industry, unveiling a funding structure under which it could take a stake of over 50% in Rapidus, the country's bet on advanced chipmaking.

Ryosei Akazawa, Japan's minister of economy, trade and industry, said Friday that the government has invested 100 billion yen, or about $640 million, in the chip maker. It has voting rights of 11.5% but with the option to boost that to more than 50% if Rapidus runs into any financial or operational problems.

The initial capital injection will be deployed immediately, with an additional 150 billion yen earmarked in the upcoming budget, bringing the government's total equity commitment in Rapidus to 250 billion yen for the 2026 fiscal year.

The move signals a shift toward a more aggressive industrial policy as Japan pushes to regain its footing in the global silicon arms race, industry analysts said.

Japan has pinned its hopes on Rapidus, a state-backed venture established in 2022 with the mission of developing home-grown advanced chipmaking capacity. It has also been courting foreign companies, seeking to bring their expertise into the domestic ecosystem.

Earlier this month, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. finalized an agreement to produce 3-nanometer chips at its second Japanese facility in Kumamoto, an upgrade from previous plans for more mature nodes.

That was a major leap for Japan, which doesn't yet have capacity to mass produce advanced chips essential for artificial intelligence.

The government has been pushing to change that, backing projects like the Kumamoto expansion, which provides a high-volume manufacturing baseline for the country. Rapidus meanwhile is focused on the even more ambitious goal of making 2-nanometer logic chips.

To further safeguard its investment in the state-backed venture, the government will hold a so-called "golden share" in Rapidus, granting it veto power over board decisions to protect against economic security risks and foreign influence.

A combined $1.07 billion investment pledge in Rapidus from 32 companies reflects renewed interest from the private sector too.

The investment pool, which includes contributions from a broad range of domestic industry leaders, surpassed the government's initial projections for private funding.

The capital commitment "exceeds the initial target of 130 billion yen," a sign that "expectations for the project are clearly mounting", Akazawa said.


Write to Yang Jie at jie.yang@wsj.com


(END) Dow Jones Newswires

02-26-26 2325ET

China conducts patrol in South China Sea, accuses Philippines of 'disrupting' peace
data.description:
BEIJING, Feb 27 (Reuters) - China's military said on Friday it conducted a routine patrol in the South China Sea from February 23 to 26, and accused the Philippines of "disrupting" peace and stability by organising joint patrols with countries outside the region.

The military's Southern Theatre Command will "resolutely safeguard China's territorial sovereignty and maritime rights and interests, and firmly uphold regional peace and stability," spokesperson Zhai Shichen said in a statement.

The navies of the Philippines, the U.S. and Japan trained alongside each other in the South China Sea this week to ramp up cooperation among the military allies, the Philippines' armed forces said on Friday.

(Reporting by Beijing Newsroom; Editing by Jacqueline Wong)

data.title: Saint-Gobain's FY25 Net Income Rises; Sales Down
How do Pakistan and Taliban Afghan militaries stack up as tensions flare?
data.description:
Feb 27 (Reuters) - Cross-border fighting between Pakistan and Afghanistan intensified overnight, with both sides claiming heavy losses and the Pakistani defence minister saying his country was in an "open war" with its neighbour.

As tensions persist, here is a look at how Pakistan dwarfs Afghanistan's military forces and arsenals, according to data from the London-based International Institute for Strategic Studies.    

OVERVIEW 

Pakistan's armed forces benefit from good recruitment and retention, bolstered by equipment from its main defence partner China. Islamabad continues to invest in its military nuclear programmes and is also modernising its navy and air force. 

The capability of the Afghan Taliban's armed forces, meanwhile, is declining, with a fall in their ability to use foreign equipment that the Islamist group seized when it returned to power in the landlocked country in 2021.

A lack of international recognition for the Taliban administration has also hurt military modernisation. 

PERSONNEL 

Pakistan has 660,000 active personnel in its defence forces, of whom 560,000 are in the army, 70,000 are in the air force, and 30,000 are in the navy.  

The strength of the Afghan Taliban's military is thinner, with only 172,000 active personnel. The group has, however, announced plans to expand its armed forces to 200,000 personnel. 

FIGHTING VEHICLES AND ARTILLERY

Pakistan has more than 6,000 armoured fighting vehicles, and over 4,600 pieces of artillery. 

The Afghan forces also possess armoured fighting vehicles, including Soviet-era main battle tanks, armoured personnel carriers and autonomous underwater vehicles, but their exact number is unknown. 

The precise number of artillery they possess, which is of at least three different types, is similarly not known. 

AIR FORCE

Pakistan has a fleet of 465 combat aircraft and more than 260 helicopters that include multi-role, attack and transport choppers.

Afghanistan has no fighter jets and no real air force to speak of. It is known to possess at least six aircraft - some of them dating back again to the Soviet era - and 23 helicopters, although it is not possible to assess how many are in flying condition.

NUCLEAR ARSENAL 

While Pakistan is a nuclear-armed country and has 170 warheads, Afghanistan does not have a nuclear arsenal.

(Compiled by Sakshi Dayal; Editing by YP Rajesh and Raju Gopalakrishnan)
